titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jacques Hnizdovsky Collection
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Alexis Knowlton

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday December 19, 2018 at 00:00

did.abstract: This small collection contains primarily examples of the bold graphic style Hnizdovsky adopted toward the end of his career in the 1970s and 1980s. Some of the prints are hand colored; many are signed editions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the artist, 1980, 1981, 1983. Gift of Stephania Hnizdovsky, 1986.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jacques Hnizdovsky Collection, Robert B. Haas Family Arts Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jacques Hnizdovsky, a Ukrainian-American woodcut artist, was born in the Ukraine in 1915. He was a student at the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw in 1939 when the Nazis invaded Poland. He made his way to the Academy of Fine Arts in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, and made his living as a freelance graphic designer. He painted and, in the early 1940s, did some woodcut work. One of his freelance jobs took him to Paris and, ultimately in 1949, to the U.S. Hnizdovsky started out in St. Paul, MN, and then moved to New York City, where he designed book jackets, posters, fabrics, illustrated books, and other jobs that allowed him to continue his painting and woodblock printmaking. He died in 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This small collection contains primarily examples of the bold graphic style Hnizdovsky adopted toward the end of his career in the 1970s and 1980s. Some of the prints are hand colored; many are signed editions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Bookplates. II. Drawings. III. Proofs. IV. Prints. V. Posters. VI. Woodblocks. VII. Biographical Materials and Small Designs.

did.unittitle: XVII Congresso Internazionale Dell'Ex Libris Lugano 1978
[Apple and walnut proofs with drawing on top]
PART THREE Soneto 1816-1818 [Keats project, spider web]
JOHN KEATS first sketches submitted - J. H. [sketches for text for Keats project]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes mock-ups for a book jacket design, title page, and headpiece.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "First sketch for the jacket which was actually used."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "intended illustration for John Keats not used, woodblock destroyed."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "Finally I have decided not to use this as the illustration. The woodblock has been destroyed."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Design includes the following quote: "There is no more pleasing exercise of the mind than gratitude."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "intended, but not used as illustration to J. Keats."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "This version have [sic] not been used on the jacket for Poems of John Keats. Instead the sketch (also in wood) for this woodcut has been used on the jacket."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes note: "From the 'Poems of John Keats.'"

did.unittitle: Jacques Hnizdovsky: Oils, Woodcuts and Drawings: May 27-June 18, 1978, The Museum of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam at 112th St., New York City
Woodcuts by Jacques Hnizdovsky, February 12-March 3, 1978, Newcomb Hall & Alderman Library, University of Virginia in Charlottesville
Hnizdovsky: Woodcuts of the Seventies, February 3–March 3 1979, Associated American Artists, 663 Fifth Avenue, New York City
Hnizdovsky: October 24 - November 3, 1980, Newcomb Hall, University of Virginia in Charlottesville
Jacques Hnizdovsky, University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Newcomb Hall, September 12-October 2, 1982

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes "Early Tulips," "Sunflower," "Lilies," and "Moses in a Boat."
